title: Who wins in a fight between two Will Smiths?
text:
To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video

It’s the dream of movie studios and age conscious celebs worldwide – to turn back the clock and act as yourself in your prime. Will Smith gets to live that dream with Gemini Man, a production that’s been worked on for 20 years (at one point Sean Connery would have starred) but had to wait for technology to catch up with its premise.

It also offers a tantalising premise on the poster – a fight between 51-year-old Smith and his early 90’s self.

Smith plays Harry, an assassin in his fifties who has seen too much death and plans to retire.

Out of nowhere, a mysterious figure starts hunting him, who turns out to be a young clone of himself (also Smith, with some motion capture trickery). Harry now must seek out his former boss (Clive Owen), the man behind all this, and avoid his younger self’s bullets without killing both of them.

Will Smith fights himself in Gemini Man (Image: Paramount Pictures)

It’s strange to see this type of film in cinemas, as it feels like a 90s action movie with its elaborate set pieces and exotic locations.

Unfortunately, it’s not a good example of one, as beyond the inventive premise there really isn’t much to enjoy.

Will Smith is convincing as both his older and younger self, but it’s not enough to save a dull story (Image: Paramount Pictures)

The script is painfully dull, with lines that shouldn’t have made it past the first draft (at one point Smith tells his colleague ‘it’s not Gun Time, it’s Coffee Time’. Seriously). It’s a straightforward chase with the older Smith using all his star power to try and make the stakes seem higher than they are. He elevates the action slightly, but not enough to make it enjoyable.

As for his young co-star, it’s startling to see Smith in his early 20s come back to life so vividly.

Clearly, an awful lot of groundbreaking work has gone into making him as realistic as possible, it’s just a shame not as much time was spent on the character.

Apart from some very forced signaling about his immaturity (he likes cereal and ice cream cones), it’s basically a blander version of Older Smith, and the two coming together does nothing beyond the initial ‘oohs’ and ‘ahhs’ of the effect.

Elsewhere, Clive Owen is all scowls as the villain. Mary Elizabeth Winstead is interesting as a fellow operative drawn into Henry’s plight, and refreshingly she’s a partner who’s as capable as he is, rather than a damsel in distress. Sadly, due to the dry script, she’s often there to find out what Smith is thinking.

Flimsy and predictable, Gemini Man is far from the best work of either Lee or Smith. It is a two-dimensional action film that seems more preoccupied with creating a gimmick and not telling a compelling story.

Who wins in a fight between two Will Smiths? Certainly not the audience.

Gemini Man is in UK cinemas 11 October.
